POR.DRECONTENT:
We have shown the existence of extension operators for the trace of a Sobolev space to an arbitrary subset of Euclidean space. Our theory has application and is closely related to applied mathematics and computer science - namely, the problems of data interpolation and manifold learning. In these problems one is given a collection of data points, say, embedded in Euclidean 3-dimensional space, and one seeks to fit the graph of a smooth function through the points in an essentially optimal way. Here essentially optimal means that there should be a prescribed bound on the size of the derivatives of the function.

At its heart, our method is based on a novel geometric decomposition of a subset of Euclidean space into certain structured components. This decomposition leads to an elegant structure for the formulas used to construct our interpolant. Based on this structure, we show that the extension operator has a simple structure which we term "assisted bounded depth." We also provide counterexamples which show that no extension operator can have an even simpler structure termed "bounded depth." The nice structure of our operators suggests that it should be possible to design an efficient algorithm to compute the underlying formulas, and thereby compute an interpolant with nearly minimal Sobolev norm. Unfortunately, the geometric decomposition used in the work described above is not constructive. We rectify this problem by introducing in another series of papers a different, more explicit decomposition that yields a constructive proof of the existence of linear extension operators. This work uses and builds upon many tools from computer science, specifically in the field of computational geometry, which are closely related to partitioning algorithms and nearest-neighbor search. The end result of our work is an efficient algorithm for the interpolation of data points in Eucidean space by smooth functions. We prove that our algorithm operates in time O(N log N), where N is the number of data points to be interpolated. This is optimal up to the log factor.
